instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2338: What is A2338? A2338 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2020 M1, Mid 2022 M2 with EMC 8162, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02020, 820-02773..
definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S2: What is PP3V3_S2? PP3V3_S2 is a typo of PP3V3_S3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Power cycling
threads.message:
Hello,

I received a board from a new m1 mbp that had some liquid spill on it, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL> was shorted because of UL000 that was dead, after removing it the board do the chime, but has no display or caps lock, but trackpads clics, I cannot find another UL000 (wifi/bt module) because I cannot find any donor board or chip, but I don't think that the board need that chip to boot.
When plugged to an external display, we can actually see the apple logo, the machine will go to 10% of the progress bar and then shut down.
<SIGNAL>SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is power cycling every 10-20s, and that is making all the current sense cycling too... I'm suspicious about <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> being bad but that would be data gone, can something make <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> cycle ?
CPU/GPU are getting hot and cold (cycle).
DFU mode is impossible because the board is cycling.
Where should I start from there ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Power cycling
threads.message:
"DFU mode is impossible because the board is cycling."
Did you try it, or just supposed that?

Can you access boot menu, or Internet Recovery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Power cycling
threads.message:
I tried with the force dfu button, i can see the mbp in apple configurator 2 for 2s and then it reboots.
No acces to any boot menu because it reboot before, but the machine can start the process to the recovery boot, but will shut down after few seconds.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Power cycling
threads.message: Did you maintain Force DFU button pressed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Power cycling
threads.message:
i tried both : to maintain and without maintaining as explained in logi wiki
Both will show the machine in ac2 only for 2s

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Power cycling
threads.message: Any idea of what can cause <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> to cycle ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Power cycling
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> steady voltage?
Board boots, but missing UL000 can cause the restart.

This board is probably waste of time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Power cycling
threads.message:
Yes <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is stable. 
Board is taking 20V and around 0.45 amps then drops to 0.12 amps.
I noticed smth strange, sometimes the board will stay at 5V, unplugging and plugging back will make it go to 20V.

It may be UL000, if no one is having a solution i’m just going to wait until a donor board is available (hoping that UL000 isnt linked with <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>…).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> M1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2338</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Power cycling
threads.message: Hi’ i’ve had a similar issue with cycling amperage. I have found it only by thermalcam. There was no signs at all and because of that my thermalcamera helped me a lot:-). My <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2</SIGNAL>-<SIGNAL>WLBT_ISNS</SIGNAL> was short on CL053 (underfilled area). ISO did not do it because the temp on damage was low (cycling). Do you have possibilities to use a Thermal camera?
